speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.5: Curriculum Update - The board will consider adoption of a new mathematics curriculum for grades 6–8, aligned with updated state standards. The proposed curriculum includes digital resources, project-based learning activities, and teacher training components. Adoption is intended to improve student outcomes in algebra readiness and standardized test performance.. Who would like to start?

speaker: davidoberg
content: Thanks, Graham. I think it’s great we’re looking at this—do we know how much the new math curriculum will cost per student?

speaker: grahampaige
content: That's a good question, David. Does anyone here know what the projected cost per student would be for this new curriculum?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Well, I guess I'm wondering, Dave, whether we need another math curriculum. I mean, there's been an initiative over the past several years to improve math instruction across the county.

speaker: judyle
content: Thanks, Kate. I agree, we’ve made progress, but I wonder how this new curriculum specifically addresses algebra readiness gaps. Could someone share data on where those gaps still exist?

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Thanks, Judith. I’d love to hear more about the specific algebra readiness gaps—are they consistent across schools or concentrated in certain areas? And who’s going to lead the professional development for teachers?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: Thank you all for these thoughtful questions. I think it's really helpful to understand exactly which groups are most affected by these gaps. Maybe we could get some data on that soon. Would any of the principals like to comment on the results of the previous math program in terms of student achievement?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: I'd like to echo my colleagues' concerns about the cost. How does the budget account for additional expenses related to implementation?

speaker: davidoberg
content: I appreciate that, Katrin. Do we have a clear breakdown of costs versus benefits, especially regarding long-term savings?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Yes, David, I would appreciate seeing that analysis. Also, I'm curious how many staff hours will go toward training.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Good point, Katrin. Are we factoring in teacher planning time for the rollout?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Probably so, David. But I don't see why we wouldn't just say that outright.

speaker: kateacuff
content: You know, maybe we're asking too many questions. I'm not sure I want to go down this path.

speaker: judyle
content: I think we’re doing well, Kate. I’m actually glad we’re digging into costs and training. Do we have estimates on how many hours each teacher might spend preparing?

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Judith, yes, please—can we get those prep hour estimates? And does the training include hands-on practice, or is it mostly theory?

speaker: judyle
content: Ellen, I second that. Hands-on practice seems critical—do we know if trainers will model lessons with real examples?

speaker: ellenosborne
content: Great question, Judith. I’d like to know—will the trainers use actual classroom materials, or just talk through them?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: I think we've got some solid questions coming up here. Judi, do you think we should bring Dr. Smith back tomorrow night to answer some of these questions? Or perhaps next week instead?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Jonno, I'd rather meet with him after the vote than before. I don't want to make his job harder.

speaker: davidoberg
content: Fair enough, Katrin. I think we should keep the door open for feedback—even after the vote.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: David, can I ask when you plan to submit written comments?

speaker: davidoberg
content: I’ll try to send mine by Thursday, Katrin—does that work for you?

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: Yeah, that works for me.

speaker: kateacuff
content: So, I suppose we'll come back to this again next week.

speaker: judyle
content: I hope so, Kate. I’d really appreciate seeing those training details before then. Could we schedule a follow-up briefing?

speaker: kateacuff
content: Well, I think we might be able to look at the proposal together. I mean, we're talking about significant changes.

speaker: grahampaige
content: Ok, that's enough, we will now vote privately.  We are voting on Agenda Item No. 3.5: Should the district adopt the proposed new mathematics curriculum for grades 6–8?.  If each of you could please record your vote in the chat, I will tally them up and announce the results.

speaker: davidoberg
content: yes

speaker: kateacuff
content: I'm not sure what my position was last time, but I am still supportive of moving forward with the adoption of the math curriculum.

speaker: judyle
content: abstain

speaker: ellenosborne
content: abstain

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: After reviewing the discussion, I'm going to vote yes. I think it makes sense to go forward with what was discussed earlier today. It gives us an opportunity to get students more engaged with math, which is something that I think all of us would like to see. And I think the way they're doing it with the program is very interesting. They're not just teaching math. They're teaching critical thinking skills, problem solving, communication. And I think that's important because I know many people out there feel that the current system isn't working.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content: abstain

speaker: grahampaige
content: The motion carries. And it was moved by Ms. Johnson, seconded by Mr. Paige, that we approve the adoption of the new math curriculum for grades six through eight. It has passed unanimously. Thank you all very much. Any other business?
